A problem with your terms. A "coverage measure" is a measure -- it does not=
 cover anything.

There are different kinds of test coverage, measured by t=
he aspects of the program they cover. 100% line coverage seems to be the mo=
st definite of the ones you list, although it does not take into account di=
fferent data sets. It is possible to have 100% line coverage and still have=
 a defect because you have not written code to handle a particular case.

I=
 do not like test coverage measurement. It is not smart enough. Obviously, =
90% coverage is much better than 50% coverage, but the return on investment=
 goes down considerably up over 90%. My opinion.

Take care.

>So said java=
insel on 2003-05-04 --------------------
>I read about Line Coverage, Branc=
h Coverage, Condition Coverage, 
>Path Coverage, Call Coverage, Loop Covera=
ge, Linear Code Sequence 
>and Jump (LCAJ) Coverage and Data Flow Coverage.=
 And also I read 
>something about Data Chains (same as Data Flow?).
>
>Is =
there a coverage measure which covers 100%?
>
>And is there a ranking of co=
verage measures in terms of how much 
>they cover compared to the other mea=
sures?
